facts.text: Chain Singh and Baldeo Singh are sons of Bhajan Singh. Gurbachan Singh is the son of Jagat Singh. The deceased Bakhsheesh Singh was the brother of Major Singh and a cousin of appellant Bhajan Singh.

Major Singh purchased land in village Paivandkheri from Sohan Singh. Gurbachan Singh was in unlawful possession of 15-16 bighas of the said land. There was litigation between Gurbachan Singh and Major Singh regarding this land. Gurbachan Singh sold his entire land including disputed area to Bhajan Singh.

Major Singh and father Ujagar Singh asked Bhajan Singh to give up possession over land purchased by Major Singh. On the day before occurrence, suggested going to Patwari to settle; Bhajan Singh agreed.
On September 17, 1964, at about 11:30 A.M., Bakhsheesh Singh started on cycle for Patwari house with papers re disputed land, followed on foot by father Ujagar Singh and brother Major Singh.
When Bakhsheesh had gone 20-25 paces from house, five appellants accosted him: Baldeo Singh armed with spear, Gurbachan Singh with gandasa, others (Bhajan, Chain, Jagat) with lathis.
Bakhsheesh got down from cycle. Bhajan Singh caught hold of him and incited others to beat him. Bakhsheesh requested appellants to accompany to Patwari; Jagat Singh said they would settle on spot.
Baldev Singh gave spear blow to abdomen; Gurbachan gave gandasa blow on head; Chain Singh beat with lathi. Appellants ran away.
Occurrence witnessed by Ujagar Singh PW3, Major Singh PW2, Jogendar Kaur widow of deceased PW4, servants Sadhu Singh, Sardari Singh, Prakash Singh.
Bakhsheesh injured in abdomen, intestines out. Bandaged with turbans of deceased and Ujagar. Taken to PS Afzalgarh; FIR lodged by Major Singh at 12:45 PM.
Sent to hospital Sherkot; examined by Dr. Yogendra Pal PW4 in Committing Court. Then to District Hospital Bijnor.
Dying declaration Ex. Ka-8 recorded at 9:30 PM by Tahsildar Magistrate Shri Balbir Singh W1.
Bakhsheesh died September 18, 1964 afternoon. Postmortem by Dr. P.P. Agarwal on September 19, 1964; death due to shock and haemorrhage from injuries.
Gurbachan Singh and Chain Singh had simple injuries; not reported to police, examined by Dr. K.C. Gupta DW4 on September 20, 1964 at 4:00 PM.
Defence of Bhajan Singh, Baldeo Singh, Jagat Singh: absolute denial.

Chain Singh version: He and Gurbachan grazing cattle by canal; Sardar Singh and Bakhsheesh came, Bakhsheesh abused, grappling; Major from behind with karauli gave blow; second attempt struck Bakhsheesh.
Gurbachan version: Tried to intervene, received lathi blows from Sardar Singh.

legal_issues.text: Whether the five appellants formed an unlawful assembly with common object to murder Bakhsheesh Singh under section 302/149 IPC, or only to beat him.
Reliability of eyewitnesses who are related to deceased.
Explanation for injuries on accused (Gurbachan and Chain Singh).
Whether case falls under section 304 IPC instead of 302/149.

petitioner_arguments.text: Eyewitnesses are partisan as related to deceased; their testimony interested.
No explanation by eyewitnesses for injuries on accused; evidence should be rejected.
Common object only to beat (word 'maro' used); not to kill; 302/149 not established.
Cited Shambhu Nath Singh v. State of Bihar and Queen v. Sabid Ali.

respondent_arguments.text: FIR mentions Jagat Singh said 'let us settle here. What will Patwari do? Kill the sala.'
All five armed with deadly weapons; Bhajan caught hold and shouted 'beat the sala'; Jagat said settle on spot, 'beat this sala'; sequence shows common object to kill.

court_reasoning.text: Slow to interfere with concurrent findings of two courts below on evidence under Art 136; no extraordinary case of gross injustice.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Eyewitnesses PW2, PW3, PW4 reliable; corroborated by dying declaration, medical evidence, Sadhu Singh under s33 Evidence Act.

court_reasoning.text: No serious infirmity in eyewitness testimony beyond being 'interested'; deceased cousin of Bhajan; perused evidence, no ground to disbelieve.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Courts below repelled arguments on medical mismatch and accused injuries with good reasons.

court_reasoning.text: Word 'maro' not decisive; see surrounding circumstances: armed with deadly weapons, Bhajan caught hold 'beat the sala', Jagat 'settle on spot, beat this sala', then spear to abdomen, gandasa to head.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Five accused members of unlawful assembly with common object to kill.

court_reasoning.text: Even if original object to beat, armed with deadly weapons (spear, gandasa, lathis), knew death likely: guilty under second limb of s149.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No circumstance to bring to s304; intention clear to kill.

court_reasoning.text: Cited cases do not help accused.
court_reasoning.key_observation: All five came armed despite prior agreement to Patwari; joint attack with one design.

court_reasoning.text: S149 constitutes substantive offence; even if object to beat, well-knit with fatal result as dangerous finale.
court_reasoning.key_observation: See K.C. Mathew v. State of Travancore-Cochin.

holdings.text: All five accused guilty under section 302/149 IPC.
No separate conviction under 147/148 needed as subsumed in 302/149.

precedents_cited.case_name: Shambhu Nath Singh v. State of Bihar
precedents_cited.relevance: Relied by appellants; court finds does not help accused.
Relied by appellants; court finds does not help accused.

precedents_cited.case_name: K.C. Mathew v. State of Travancore-Cochin
precedents_cited.relevance: Supports that common object to beat with deadly weapons leads to liability under 302/149.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Conviction under 302/149 upheld; 147/148 set aside as subsumed; not 304.

statutes_cited.name: Evidence Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Statement of Sadhu Singh in Committing Court admitted in Sessions Court.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Appeal by special leave; slow to interfere with concurrent findings.

outcome.summary: Conviction and life sentence under section 302/149 IPC affirmed for all five appellants. Conviction and sentences under section 147 IPC for Bhajan Singh, Chain Singh, Jagat Singh and under section 148 IPC for Baldeo Singh, Gurbachan Singh set aside as no further necessity.

key_quotes.text: 'beat the sala' (Bhajan Singh); 'settle on spot... beat this sala' (Jagat Singh)
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Shows incitement and common object beyond mere beating.

key_quotes.text: If an offence is committed... such as the members... knew to be likely... every person... is guilty of that offence.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains second limb of section 149 IPC applied here.
